dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, I was watching the, um, you know, the recent political convention, and it just struck me how much of a spectacle it was. Like, all the glitzy musical acts, the rousing speeches, floods of tears, Oprah!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, I was watching the, um, you know, the recent political convention, and it just struck me how much of a spectacle it was. Like, all the glitzy musical acts, the rousing speeches, floods of tears, Oprah!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It had everything: glitzy musical acts, rousing speeches, religious devotion, floods of tears, promises of hope, moments of joy, uplifting patriotism, Oprah Winfrey, and lots and lots of balloons.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. And the balloons, right? So many balloons! I was actually thinking about Vice President Harris, and just, uh, how commentators were marveling at her whole presentation – her smile, her body language...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. And the balloons, right? So many balloons! I was actually thinking about Vice President Harris, and just, uh, how commentators were marveling at her whole presentation - her smile, her body language...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Television commentators marveled at the way Vice President Kamala Harris presented herself: her smile, her body language, her voice, even her choice of clothing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah! It’s like, politics in America, it’s not just about policy, it’s, like, completely indistinguishable from entertainment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah! It's like, politics in America, it's not just about policy, it's, like, completely indistinguishable from entertainment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But in the United States, politics has long been indistinguishable from entertainment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. There's this old, um, journalist, H.L. Mencken, who apparently said way back in 1927 that the US was "incomparably the greatest show on earth." And that was about political conventions even then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. There's this old, um, journalist, H.L. Mencken, who apparently said way back in nineteen twenty seven that the U S was incomparably the greatest show on earth. And that was about political conventions even then.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The caustic American journalist H.L. Mencken, who despised politicians and thought most Americans were ignorant oafs, was a great observer of political party conventions. He wrote in 1927: The United States, to my eye, is incomparably the greatest show on earth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? It's wild how little has changed. But okay, here's what gets me: why do candidates *have* to make such a show of loving their families? All that hugging and kissing on stage?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? It's wild how little has changed. But okay, here's what gets me: why do candidates have to make such a show of loving their families? All that hugging and kissing on stage?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, god, the family moments. It’s like, is that performance of devotion truly necessary to win over voters?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, god, the family moments. It's like, is that performance of devotion truly necessary to win over voters?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, apparently it is in America. Because, you know, in most other democracies, people vote for parties and interests. Charisma plays a role, sure, but Asian or European politicians aren't nearly as eager to sell themselves as, like, warm, loving human beings.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, apparently it is in America. Because, you know, in most other democracies, people vote for parties and interests. Charisma plays a role, sure, but Asian or European politicians aren't nearly as eager to sell themselves as, like, warm, loving human beings.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In most democracies, people vote for political parties and the interests they represent. Charisma plays a role even in countries like Japan, where most politicians are singularly lacking in that quality. But overall, Asian and European politicians are not nearly as eager or as willing as Americans to sell themselves to the public as warm and loving human beings.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's true. They don't typically do that "I'm just like you, come have a beer" thing, do they?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's true. They don't typically do that I'm just like you, come have a beer thing, do they?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No! It's almost like, um, we expect that from royalty, not elected politicians. It's so weird.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No! It's almost like, um, we expect that from royalty, not elected politicians. It's so weird.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That is what people have traditionally wanted from kings and queens, not elected politicians.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It *is* weird. And the article actually brought up this point that the White House, it's acquired almost, like, quasi-monarchical trappings.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is weird. And the article actually brought up this point that the White House, it's acquired almost, like, quasi-monarchical trappings.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the intervening years, the White House has acquired much of the pomp and circumstance of a royal court, to an extent that far exceeds that of other democracies except perhaps France, where the republic is still dressed up in royal grandeur. America's New China Narrative Чиа To ascend to the US presidency, with all its quasi-monarchical trappings, a candidate like the British royals must make a great show of being a regular guy or gal, a person like you and me, someone to have a beer with on the front porch.

dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's like our version of a royal court, even though we, like, broke away from King George III.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's like our version of a royal court, even though we, like, broke away from King George the Third.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Americans liberated themselves from the British monarchy in 1776 (Farmer George was their last king). In the intervening years, the White House has acquired much of the pomp and circumstance of a royal court...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! So, to become president, you have to do this whole act of being a "regular guy or gal," someone you could, you know, have a beer with on the front porch. Even though, like, they're clearly not regular.

People who aspire to be president are not really like us, of course, but they must pretend to be.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: They're definitely not. But that sentimental gush, it's not just politics, either. Think about Oscar acceptance speeches.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They're definitely not. But that sentimental gush, it's not just politics, either. Think about Oscar acceptance speeches.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the sentimental gush of US party conventions the hugging, the kissing, and the effusions of familial love is conspicuous in other American ceremonial occasions, too. Foreign recipients of an Oscar, for example, tend to keep acceptance speeches crisp and short.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, god, yes! The tearful thanks to elementary school teachers and pet dogs!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, god, yes! The tearful thanks to elementary school teachers and pet dogs!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Not the American stars, who must tearfully thank everyone from their primary schoolteachers to their pet dogs, and express their deep devotion to humanity.

dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Foreign recipients keep it crisp, but American stars have to, like, express their deep devotion to humanity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Foreign recipients of an Oscar, for example, tend to keep acceptance speeches crisp and short. Not the American stars, who must tearfully thank everyone from their primary schoolteachers to their pet dogs, and express their deep devotion to humanity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's this public performance of love or grief or hope, isn't it? When, really, politics and Hollywood are, like, ruthlessly competitive businesses where private feelings often have to be suppressed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's this public performance of love or grief or hope, isn't it? When, really, politics and Hollywood are, like, ruthlessly competitive businesses where private feelings often have to be suppressed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Sentimentality is misplaced emotion, a public performance of love, grief, hope, and joy, rather than the real thing, which is normally kept private. Politics, like the Hollywood film industry, is in fact a ruthlessly competitive business, where private feelings ones own as well as those of others often must be ignored or suppressed to get ahead.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's this paradox. We want them to be authentic, but they have to *perform* authenticity. Like, the article says, the performance of authenticity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it's this paradox. We want them to be authentic, but they have to perform authenticity. Like, the article says, the performance of authenticity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: What we see, then, at the party convention and the Oscar ceremony, in the television interview and the magazine profile, is the performance of authenticity.

dialogue_turns.text: Which, in the right hands, like at some of these conventions, can really still feel like, um, the greatest show on earth.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, in the right hands, like at some of these conventions, can really still feel like, um, the greatest show on earth.
